vo:
How do we address the energy concerns relative to the bitcoin protocol? We can take a technical approach, a market approach, a political approach, or a combination any of them. 

Given the distribution of the protocol, the only ways of influencing the mining of bitcoin politically are by:
• banning, moving bitcoin mining to other jurisdiction
• tax incentives or penalizations, attracting or detracting miners
• energy subsidies, using tax payer money and creating an imbalance in the energy usage

The market could also influence by adding a premium to bitcoin mined from miners or pools that market themselves as mining more efficiently and less destructively for the environment, but so far we've seen little interest from the market on pricing bitcoin from different origins differently. (we've seen exchanges limit access or refuse to accept bitcoin with coinjoin history)

The foundational immutability principles of bitcoin have created a consensus amongst the nodes that, in the case of a push to change the proof-of-work protocol, the change may not be accepted by a large portion of the network. This keeps the miners committed to the network as they risk having their block rejected by some nodes and delay its propagation or rejection.

The optimal solution would be to have miners invested in the long term sustainability of the area in which they operate, and the world. Potentially building small communities around miners and absorve the overflow of the cities.

Previously isolated areas now have a way to generate capital independently. If planned long term, these ventures, originally envisioned as factories, can become smaller pocket populations.
